natural problem: A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to?
natural solution: The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [13, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [5, -12]"
and h2 : "c = vector [0, 1]"
and h3 : "rotation_matrix a b"
shows  "rotation_matrix c = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "a = vector [13, 0]"
and h1 : "b = vector [5, -12]"
and h2 : "c = vector [0, 1]"
and h3 : "rotation_matrix a b"
shows  "rotation_matrix c = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Assume we have three 2D vectors: 
- Vector a pointing at [13, 0]
- Vector b pointing at [5, -12]
- Vector c pointing at [0, 1]

If vector a is rotated to match vector b, what is the rotation matrix when applied to vector c? The final answer is [12/13, 5/13].

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes R :: "real^2^2" and v w :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "R *\<^sub>R vector [13, 0] = vector [5, -12]"
and h1 : "orthogonal_matrix R"
and h2 : "R *\<^sub>R vector [0, 1] = v"
shows  "v = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes R :: "real^2^2" and v w :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "R *\<^sub>R vector [13, 0] = vector [5, -12]"
and h1 : "orthogonal_matrix R"
and h2 : "R *\<^sub>R vector [0, 1] = v"
shows  "v = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given that a 2x2 real orthogonal matrix $R$ multiplied by the vector $[13, 0]$ gives the vector $[5, -12]$, and that $R$ multiplied by the vector $[0, 1]$ gives the vector $v$, find the vector $v$. The final answer is $v = [12/13, 5/13]$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes origin :: "real^2" 
and v1 v2 v3 :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "origin = vector [0, 0]"
and h1 : "v1 = vector [13, 0]"
and h2 : "v2 = vector [5, -12]"
and h3 : "v3 = vector [0, 1]"
and h4 : "\<forall> v. v - origin = rotation_matrix 2 (acos ((v1 \<bullet> v2) / (\<parallel>v1\<parallel> * \<parallel>v2\<parallel>))) *v* (v - origin)"
shows  "rotation v3 = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes origin :: "real^2" 
and v1 v2 v3 :: "real^2"
assumes h0 : "origin = vector [0, 0]"
and h1 : "v1 = vector [13, 0]"
and h2 : "v2 = vector [5, -12]"
and h3 : "v3 = vector [0, 1]"
and h4 : "\<forall> v. v - origin = rotation_matrix 2 (acos ((v1 \<bullet> v2) / (\<parallel>v1\<parallel> * \<parallel>v2\<parallel>))) *v* (v - origin)"
shows  "rotation v3 = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Consider the 2D Cartesian coordinate system with origin at point [0,0], vector v1 at [13,0], vector v2 at [5,-12] and vector v3 at [0,1]. The rotation of any vector v around the origin is defined by the rotation_matrix function that takes as parameters the dimension and the angle between vectors v1 and v2. Find the coordinates of the rotated vector v3. The final answer is [12/13, 5/13].

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes v w :: "real ^ 2" and R :: "real ^ 2 => real ^ 2"
assumes h0 : "R (vector [13, 0]) = vector [5, -12]"
and h1 : "linear R"
and h2 : "orthogonal_matrix R"
shows  "R (vector [0, 1]) = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes v w :: "real ^ 2" and R :: "real ^ 2 => real ^ 2"
assumes h0 : "R (vector [13, 0]) = vector [5, -12]"
and h1 : "linear R"
and h2 : "orthogonal_matrix R"
shows  "R (vector [0, 1]) = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given a linear transformation R that is represented by an orthogonal matrix, if R transforms the vector [13, 0] to the vector [5, -12], find the image of the vector [0, 1] under the transformation R. The final answer is the vector [12/13, 5/13].

a_4.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes rotation :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "rotation (vector [13, 0]) = vector [5, -12]"
shows  "rotation (vector [0, 1]) = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem 
fixes rotation :: "real^2 \<Rightarrow> real^2"
assumes h0 : "rotation (vector [13, 0]) = vector [5, -12]"
shows  "rotation (vector [0, 1]) = vector [12/13, 5/13]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "Given a rotation function that transforms the 2D vector [13, 0] to [5, -12], find the resultant vector when the function is applied to the vector [0, 1]. The final answer is [12/13, 5/13]."

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rotation :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "rotation (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. rotation (x, y) = (x * cos (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)) - y * sin (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)), x * sin (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)) + y * cos (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)))"
shows  "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes rotation :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "rotation (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. rotation (x, y) = (x * cos (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)) - y * sin (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)), x * sin (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)) + y * cos (angle_between (13, 0) (5, -12)))"
shows  "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a rotation of the point (13, 0) results in the point (5, -12), find the coordinates of the point (0, 1) after the same rotation. The final answer is (12/13, 5/13).

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rotation :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "rotation (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
shows  "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes rotation :: "(real*real) \<Rightarrow> (real*real)"
assumes h0 : "rotation (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
shows  "rotation (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given that the rotation of the point (13, 0) results in the point (5, -12), and that the rotation of the point (0, 1) results in the point (12/13, 5/13), confirm that the rotation of the point (0, 1) indeed results in the point (12/13, 5/13).

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 13"
and h1 : "y = 0"
and h2 : "rotate x y = (5, -12)"
shows  "rotate 0 1 = (12/13, 5/13)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 13"
and h1 : "y = 0"
and h2 : "rotate x y = (5, -12)"
shows  "rotate 0 1 = (12/13, 5/13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume that a rotation transformation has been applied to the point (13, 0) and the result is the point (5, -12). Based on this transformation, find the new coordinates of the point (0, 1) after the same rotation. The final answer is (12/13, 5/13).

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rotate :: "real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real \<times> real"
assumes h0 : "rotate (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. rotate (x, y) = (y, -x)"
shows  "rotate (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes rotate :: "real \<times> real \<Rightarrow> real \<times> real"
assumes h0 : "rotate (13, 0) = (5, -12)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x y. rotate (x, y) = (y, -x)"
shows  "rotate (0, 1) = (12/13, 5/13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a rotation function that transforms a pair of real numbers (x, y) to (y, -x), if the transformation of (13, 0) is (5, -12), find the result of transforming (0, 1). The final answer is (12/13, 5/13).

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rotate :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rotate 13 0 = (5, -12)"
shows  "rotate 0 1 = (12 / 13, 5 / 13)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A rotation centered at the origin takes $\begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}$ to $\begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.$  Which vector does the rotation take $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ to? The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 The rotation matrix must be of the form $\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix}.$  Thus, \[\begin{pmatrix} \cos \theta & -\sin \theta \\ \sin \theta & \cos \theta \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 13 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 \\ -12 \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $\cos \theta = \frac{5}{13}$ and $\sin \theta = -\frac{12}{13}.$  Thus, $\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}$ is taken to
 \[\begin{pmatrix} \frac{5}{13} & \frac{12}{13} \\ -\frac{12}{13} & \frac{5}{13} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 12/13 \\ 5/13 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes rotate :: "real \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "rotate 13 0 = (5, -12)"
shows  "rotate 0 1 = (12 / 13, 5 / 13)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If rotating a point 13 units results in the point (5, -12), what will be the result of rotating a point 1 unit? The final answer is (12/13, 5/13).
